getWorldMap

public java.util.Hashtable getWorldMap()
Returns a hash that contains array of hashtables representing all of the towns you can see, an array of hashtables of the Map Tiles you can see(these are the large backgrounds behind your cities), and the cloud base hashtable that you can see.

To grab the array of town hashtables, use the key "townHash". Each hashtable in the town hashtable array has keys "townName","owner","pid","SSL", "resEffects"(an array), "debris"(an array), "x", "y", "dig"(which returns true if a dig is present.),"taxRate"(a double which is zero if you cannot see it, or the actual tax rate if this is one of your towns or a town you have vassaled.)

To grab the maptile array of hashtables, use the key "tileHash". Each entry is a hashtable containing these keys: mid, an integer identifier for the tile, centerx, an integer that represents the at what spot the center of this map tile is in the x,y space of towns, centery, and finally mapName, the filename of the map tile being used.

To grab the array of territory hashtables, use the key "territoryArray"

territory entry data key:
[] means an array
{} means a Hashtable
"id"->object is a key-value pair

The entry data is exemplified by: 

[
        {
                "id"->UUID -- Unique ID used by the backend to help sort territories.
                                These ids are not saved across server restarts.

                (the corners hashtable is the only part used by the front end, so all info necessary for territorial identification by the WM goes in the corners block)

                "corners" -> {

                        "owner"->"SomeGuy"
                        "lord"->"yourLordsUsername"(if you are a Vassal) or "none"
                        "corner"-> [1,1]
                        "sides"-> [2,3,4]

                };

                    (the points array is used by the backend for territory comparison, so it does not need or contain ownership info)
                    "points"(an array of Hashtables) -> 
                [
                        {
                                x->1
                                y->1
                        },
                        {
                                x->3
                                y->1
                        },
                        {
                                x->3
                                y->4
                        },
                        {
                                x->7
                                y->4
                        }
                ]
        },
        {
                ...
        }
]
To grab the array of cloud hashtables, use the key "cloudHash".

Each hashtable entry in the array has the following keys: centerx, centery, incs, size, velocity, ticksToDeath, direction. All variables are integers except incs, which is a double array representing the cloud effects, and velocity, which is a double representing movement spaces/hr. Be aware that ticks in cloud space are hour long ticks, not GCF-long ticks like other timers in the game. Each entry in incs signifies:

Combat incs:
  1. conc
  2. armor
  3. cargo
  4. speed
  5. firepower
  6. amm
  7. acc
ResIncs:
  1. metal
  2. timber
  3. manmat
  4. food
  5. Engineer Effectiveness(Bldg times)
  6. Trader Effectiveness(Better SM trades)
  7. Scholar Effectiveness(Increased Knowledge Percentage)

sendMessage

public boolean sendMessage(java.lang.String[] usernameTo,
                           java.lang.String body,
                           java.lang.String subject,
                           java.util.UUID original_subject_id)
UI Implemented.

Sends a message to the array of player names specified in usernameTo. original_subject_id needs to be 0 if this message is not in reply to another or if you do not wish it to be!

Parameters:
usernameTo - an array of usernames to send this message to. Invalid usernames will cause this message to be sent to Id.
body - the body of the message
subject - the subject of the message
original_message_id - The original message ID, 0 if none. Used for chaining messages together.
Returns:
True, if the message was sent. False otherwise.

setUpTradeSchedule

public boolean setUpTradeSchedule(int tid1,
                                  int m,
                                  int t,
                                  int mm,
                                  int f,
                                  long otherm,
                                  long othert,
                                  long othermm,
                                  long otherf,
                                  int intervaltime,
                                  int timesToDo)
UI Implemented.

Sets up an open two way trade schedule. intervaltime is in seconds and is how long the system will wait before making the next trade, timesToDo is how many times you wish to have the trade executed, and tid1 is your town ID.

Parameters:
tid1 - the ID of your town
m - the amount of metal you're offering
t - the amount of timber you're offering
mm - the amount of crystal you're offering
f - the amount of food you're offering
otherm - the amount of metal you want in return
othert - the amount of timber you want in return
othermm - the amount of crystal you want in return
otherf - the amount of food you want in return
intervaltime - the amount of time, in seconds, between each trade
timesToDo - the number of times this trade should be repeated
Returns:
True, if the Trade Schedule was set up. False otherwise.

y - the y coordinate of the target town
m - the amount of metal to send
t - the amount of timber to send
mm - the amount of crystla to send
f - the amount of food to send
intervaltime - the amount of time, in seconds, between each trade
timesToDo - the number of times this trade should be performed
Returns:
True, if the Trade Schedule was set up. False otherwise.
See Also:
UserTradeSchedule, USerTrade

combatSimulator

public boolean combatSimulator(java.lang.String[] offAUNames,
                               java.lang.String[] defAUNames,
                               int[] offAUSizes,
                               int[] defAUSizes,
                               java.lang.String[] offTownBuildings,
                               java.lang.String[] defTownBuildings,
                               int[] offTownBuildingLevels,
                               int[] defTownBuildingLevels,
                               java.lang.String attackType,
                               java.lang.String[] target)
THIS METHOD IS NOT COMPLETE! This is the combat sim. To use it, send in an array of names for the def and off. An example would be ["Pillager","Seeker"]. Then, make an integer array of the same size and send in the sizes of each unit. You can do the same with buildings in each town, since buildings contribute to combat as well: ["Command Center","Fortification", "Resource Cache", "Resource Cache"], and then you can send in the levels of each one.

The combat sim will spit out an SR into your SR box.

Parameters:
offAUNames - an array containing the names of all the units to use on offense.
defAUNames - an array containing the names of all the units to use on defense.
offAUSizes - an array containing the sizes of all the units to use on offense. Should be the same size as offAUNames.
defAUSizes - an array containing the sizes of all the units to use on defense. Should be the same size as defAUNames.
offTownBuildings - an array containing the names of buildings to be added to the offender's town.
defTownBuildings - an array containing the names of buildings to be added to the defender's town.
offTownBuildingLevels - an array containing the levels of the buildings in the offender's town. Should be the same size as offTownBuildings.
defTownBuildingLevels - an array containing the levels of the buildings in the defender's town. Should be the same size as defTownBuildings.
attackType - the type of attack to send. See attack for a list of valid attack types.
target - the buildings to target if this is a bombing run.
Returns:
False

returnPrice

public long[] returnPrice(java.lang.String unitType,
                          int number,
                          int tid,
                          boolean minus)
If minus is false, then it gets the price of the next number of soldiers. If minus is true, it gets the price of the most recent number made. Example: if minus is false, and you have 100 soldiers, and you ask for the price of 5, it gives you the price of the 101st,102nd,103rd,104th,105th soldier summed. If minus is true, and you have 100 soldiers, and you ask for the price of 5, it gives you the price of the 96th,97th,98th,99th,100th soldier prices summed.

Parameters:
unitType - - String name of the unit
number - - Number of units to build
tid - - ID of the town they're being built in
minus - - if true, gives the price of the last number of units, instead of the next
Returns:
long[] {metal, timber, manmat, food, expMod}

getGameClockFactor

public double getGameClockFactor()
Returns in seconds, the tick rate of God. This is the unit that all timers in the game are in when you use programming. For instance, the eta() method of UserRaid returns a number of ticks till you hit the guy - these ticks are in units of GCF, which is some number of seconds. So if the GCF is 10, and the ETA given by a UserRaid is 9, then the actual time till the raid hits is 10*9=90 secs.

Returns:

attack

public boolean attack(int yourTownID,
                      int enemyx,
                      int enemyy,
                      int[] auAmts,
                      java.lang.String attackType,
                      java.lang.String[] target,
                      java.lang.String name,
                      boolean send)
UI Implemented.

Sends a mission, or checks if a mission could be sent with the auAmts specified, attackType chosen, and bomb target designated(ignored if not a bombing run).

Note: If you attack a city with an Airship above it and that city is an ID city, you will hit the Airship. If you hit a player-owned city with an Airship above it, you will hit the city but can kill the Airship above it if you wipe all of it's troops out.

If you aim at an Airship directly, you may not commit Sieges or Glassings on it.

valid attackTypes:
  • attack
  • siege
  • glass
  • strafe
  • invasion
  • scout
  • offsupport
  • support
  • debris
  • dig
  • excavation
  • blockade

Parameters:
yourTownID - ID of the town you're sending from.
enemyx - The x coordinate of the target town.
enemyy - The y coordinate of the target town.
auAmts - The amount of units to send. Should be of equal in length to your number of AU + any support units you wish to send.
attackType - The type of mission to send. See above for valid types.
target - An array of building names to target, if bombing. Ex. {"Command Center","Trade Center"}
name - The name of this mission. This is purely cosmetic.
send - If true, attack() tries to send the mission. If false, attack() checks if this mission could be sent.
Returns:
True, if the mission was, or could be sent. False otherwise.

changeBombTarget

public boolean changeBombTarget(java.util.UUID raidID,
                                java.lang.String[] newTarget,
                                int yourTownID)
UI Implemented.

Allows you to change the bombing target of a Strafing or Glassing mission. raidID is the identifier for your raid, and yourTownID the town of the raid's origination, and is given to speed up the search algorithm. newTarget is the new target designation.
See UserBuilding for a list of valid building types.

Parameters:
raidID - the ID of the raid to be modified
newTarget - a String array of the building types to be targeted
yourTownID - the ID of the town you sent the raid from
Returns:
True, if the bombing target was successfully changed. False otherwise.

                        int[] auAmts,
                        int yourTownID)
UI Implemented.

Sends a resupply raid to a Siege or Glassing campaign designated by the raidID and originating town of the raid, yourTownID. auAmts is the amount of each unit you want to send, size is equal to your number of unlocked units + however many support units you have.

Parameters:
raidID - the ID of the raid to be resupplied
auAmts - the amounts of units to resupply this raid with.
yourTownID - the ID of the town the raid originated from.
Returns:
True, if the resupply mission was sent. False otherwise.

recall

                      int pidOfRecallTown,
                      int yourTownID)
UI Implemented.

This recalls all support units from the town designated by town id, of the player designated by pidOfRecallTown, to your town by the town id of destinationTown.
This is a shortcut of recall(int[] auAmts, int townToRecallFromID, int pidOfRecallTown, int yourTownID) for when you want to recall all units.

Parameters:
townToRecallFromID - the ID of the town you're recalling from
pidOfRecallTown - the ID of the player that owns the town you're recalling from
yourTownID - the Id of the town you sent the support from
Returns:

updateUserGroup

public boolean updateUserGroup(java.lang.String name,
                               java.lang.String[] toAdd,
                               boolean del)
Updates a user group to add/remove new names. This completely erases the old user group, though, so please be careful to include all the original names as well!

Parameters:
name - the name of the UserGroup to update
toAdd - an array of Player names to add to the UserGroup
del - If true, toAdd becomes "toRemove" and these names are removed, if possible.
Returns:
True, if the UserGroup was updated. False otherwise.
See Also:
UserGroup

createTPR

public boolean createTPR(double taxRate,
                         int pid,
                         java.lang.String rank,
                         int type,
                         int[] tids)
UI Implemented.

Create a new TPR. Must be done from a League player. taxRate is to be between 0-1, and tids is an array of townIDs that you want this player to be able to administrate for you.

Parameters:
taxRate - the percentage of resources to deduct from the player with this rank (as a decimal). IE .1 for 10%
pid - the ID of the player this rank will apply to
rank - the name to give this rank
type - the numerical level of access this player has. 0 for members, 1 for officers, 2 for administrators
tids - the IDs of all the league towns this player has access to. Only applicable if the player is of type 1 or higher.
Returns:
True, if the TPR was successfully created. False otherwise.

getUserBuildings

private UserBuilding[] getUserBuildings(int tid,
                                        java.lang.String type,
                                        boolean free)

getUserBuildings

public UserBuilding[] getUserBuildings(int tid,
                                       java.lang.String type)
Returns an array of UserBuilding objects from the town id. This is different from getBuildings which just returns the types!

Put in the type you want. Special types: "all" returns all buildings, and "CombatProduction" returns all military unit production buildings.

Parameters:
tid - the ID of the town to get the buildings from
type - the type of building to get
Returns:
an array of UserBuildings or null, if type does not match any buildings or an error occurred.

getUserBuildingServer

public UserBuilding[] getUserBuildingServer(int tid,
                                            java.lang.String type)
Get only buildings that are on the building server. Buildings on the building server are currently being constructed, or destructed.
"all" returns all buildings, "CombatProduction" returns all combat unit production buildings.

Parameters:
tid - the ID of the town to get the buildings from
type - the type of buildings to get
Returns:
an array of USerBuildings or null, if type matched no buildings or an error occurred.

getUserAttackUnits

public UserAttackUnit[] getUserAttackUnits()
Returns an array of the user's attack units. They are of size zero as they are the models for the ones in the UserTowns. They are stored at the UserPlayer level, not the UserTown level.

an array of UserTowns representing the players towns or null, if an error occurred.

getUserTownsSlim

public UserTown[] getUserTownsSlim()
Deprecated. Use getUserTowns() instead.

Returns UserTowns just as getUserTowns does. This used to be a slimmer method for quicker load times, but with the switch back to Memory from ORM, is no longer strictly necessary.

getStockMarketRates

public float[][] getStockMarketRates(int tid)
UI Implemented. Returns a matrix of stock market rates. So rate[1][0] is how much metal(index 0) you get for one timber(index 1). This matrix should be symmetric. This matrix takes into account local weather conditions and the trade technology level of the player, which alters the exchange rates significantly.

canLaunchNuke

public boolean canLaunchNuke(int bid,
                             int x,
                             int y,
                             boolean nukeMode)
UI Implemented.

Returns if it's possible to launch the nuke in the building ID given at the coordinates given.
False nukeMode is a ground nuke, true is a sky nuke.

Parameters:
bid - the ID of the Missile Silo whose nuke you want to launch
x - the x coordinate of the target town
y - the y coordinate of the target town
nukeMode - If true, this nuke will detonate as an EMP, shutting down play AIs. Otherwise, it will detonate on the ground and do damage.
Returns:
True, if the nuke can be launched. False otherwise.

launchNuke

public boolean launchNuke(int bid,
                          int x,
                          int y,
                          boolean nukeMode)
UI Implemented.

The holy of holies, this launches the big one. If nukeMode is false, then this is a groundNuke and will do building damage. Otherwise, it's an EMP and will shut down AIs.

Parameters:
bid - the Id of the Missile Silo you're launching from
x - the x coordinate of the target town
y - the y coordinate of the target town
nukeMode - if true, this nuke detonates as an EMP. Otherwise, this nuke detonates on the gound.
Returns:
True, if launch was successful. False, otherwise.

getPlayerLevelVassalPids

public int[] getPlayerLevelVassalPids()
Returns a list of pids of your player-level vassals. Note the difference here: You can have influence over some of a player's towns, but if you have influence over enough of them, you are lord over all of them(ie, lord over the player.) This is a list of player-level vassals.

getPlayerLevelVassalUsernames

public java.lang.String[] getPlayerLevelVassalUsernames()
Returns a list of usernames of your player-level vassals. Note the difference here: You can have influence over some of a player's towns, but if you have influence over enough of them, you are lord over all of them(ie, lord over the player.) This is a list of player-level vassals.

                              double rate)

                              double rate)

rate - the tax rate percent for this vassal as a decimal(IE .1 for 10%). Can not exceed 50%.

cancelVassalage

public boolean cancelVassalage()
